text: I went to the Supper club last night for Ella Fitzgerald's birthday celebration. The performance was not worth the 40 dollars per person I spent. The place was tiny, it's an over priced hole in the wall. They claimed to have soul food on the menu, but the food much like the place lacked any such thing. The food portions are disrespectfully small, and my food was lukewarm at best. I ordered the lobster bouillabaisse, which didn't have lobster, but beyond baby langostino tails. The menu said that the dish came with shrimp, and scallops. The shrimp, and scallops all fit into the clams, and mussels. This place is shitty, you can't even move at your table if you happen to enjoy the music. I'm slim, I could barely fit in between the tables to get up to use the bathroom in this cramped place, and to exacerbate the issue the food is just as small, and the people are bougie. If you're looking to have a good time, hear good music, and eat don't go to the Supper club. If you're anorexic, rich, and pretentious this is you place.I wouldn't give this place the 1 star that I did, but I didn't have a  choice.
Went there today! Was excellent! Cynthia Scott was amazing! Have been to Smoke a few times before, Cynthia Scott was the best I have seen there, amazing voice! Food and service were great as usual.
Don't get fooled by the token black guy behind the bar - this place is racist!

Honestly and truly, Smoke Jazz is awesome. I've heard so many wonderful things about Smoke Jazz and I've been trying to get there for at least the past two years. For some reason or another, I could seem to get there but that's where NYC restaurant week comes in. Btw... If you haven't taken advantage of NYC restaurant week, boy oh boy are you missing out. Now back to Smoke Jazz, as I mentioned, restaurant week has made it possible for me to try several restaurants that I might not otherwise get to and Smoke Jazz is one of them. The restaurant is small and intimate but this amplifies the overall experience. Once the music begins, you really feel as if the musicians are playing just for you. There is not a bad seat in the house. If you arrive early, you should be able to request a table that works for you but of course, that would mean you plan to have dinner at a table and not the bar area. Don't get me wrong, the bar area is ok too. Keep in mind, there is a music/performance upcharge on your bill once the show is over. It's worth it. Before I get into the excitement food, let me take a moment to acknowledge the entire staff. Smoke Jazz operates like a well-oiled machine. I was very impressed with the efficiency of the whole operation. The wait staff is very knowledgeable about the menu and are willing to answer any questions. Now on to the food. I had the wedge salad and lobster ravioli. Incredible... Is one word that comes to mind. I even had the brownies for dessert and even that was delicious. Well, I'm sure your wondering by now, what about the music? Well, music is a form of art and up to interpretation and although I enjoyed the show and my entire experience at Smoke Jazz, let me take this moment to encourage you to stop reading this and make your reservation now! It's a magical night you will cherish for the rest of your life. Enjoy

Beautiful, great music, great ambiance. My only suggestion is more vegetarian options. All we could get was ratatouille. It was good, but we had no other choice and we had to get an entree. Our waitress was great, and we had a great time otherwise.

Smoke Jazz Club is well worth the trip to the 103rd St stop off the 1 train. I went with 3 friends on a Tuesday night to celebrate one of their birthdays and we had an awesome time - tickets for the show were only $15, and then we decided to utilize the dinner reservation that comes along with that (though I *think* that's optional and you can just sit at the bar).The food was a bit pricey but very very good - I'd highly recommend their salmon and trying their mojito. And we also split the calamari, Louisiana shrimp poppers, and croquettes - all of which were quite tasty.Oh, and did I forget to mention that the jazz performance itself was absolutely incredible? Even though it was just a Tuesday night, the act we saw was super talented and impressive. Overall, I'd highly recommend going to Smoke!

The place is beautiful and have good artists coming but it's so pretentious! The food is discusting and super expensive the cocktail shrimp it is 4 shrimps for $20 and they request people to order at least one entrée and appetizer there in addition to the fee to go inside and in less than one hour.

I had the unfortunate experience of meeting the owner of this establishment as a local resident to the area. This person acted as a very entitled and rude person and I could never advise anyone patronizing his investment. Terrible human in my personal experience

Absolutely Great music, but terrible food.On the weekends it's $40 cover charge and each person must get an entree. Entrees are about $38 which I wouldn't mind if they tasted good but unfortunately they didn't. We got the shrimp cocktail which came with 4 shrimps (hehe) & this calamari could be like a $5 calamari from the cheapest restaurant. Ugh. Terrible.We had a 9pm show, were asked arrive at 8:30. We were told we must leave by 10. So for 1.5 hours we spent about $120 per person for terrible food. I would pay $40 for the show again, but the expensive food tasted so bad that I do not recommend this place. Unfortunately won't be coming here again & do Not recommend it. I really wanted to like it but nothing makes up for mandatory, bad, expensive food. Thumbs down!

This was my first time coming to Smoke in a few years and the quality has dropped significantly all around.  I'm disappointed because this used to be one of my favorite places. First, the service was very slow. And the people sitting on either side of us were complaining of the same thing. In addition, the quality of the food was nowhere near as good as it used to be. We had the pork chop and the salmon. Both were bland and uninspired. The mac and cheese that came with the pork chop tasted like it came from a Kraft box, but with less cheese. In terms of drinks, the old fashioned tasted watered down so I switched to beer immediately after the first one. Also note that the prix fixe dessert of chocolate covered strawberries was literally just one chocolate covered strawberry. Another big letdown. What saved the experience was the act that performed; they were amazing. But at such an expensive price point, I expected much more, especially after having been here so many times in the past. Most importantly: be aware that there is a $45 per person music charge in addition to dinner. I would recommend buying tickets in advance online, where they go for $20 per person. The markup at the door is ridiculous. Don't think I'll be back until there's a change in management.

Such a wonderful experience. I took my girlfriend for her birthday and we both had a great time. If I could remember correctly, I had the blackened sea bass which was cooked to perfection. Listening to live music while dining was different for me, very enjoyable. I recommended it to a few of my friends.

SmokeLet's start on a positive note, I love the look of this bar, it reminds you of a bar from back in the day. The music from the band was amazing to say the least. Me and my wife came here to eat as well and the food wasn't good at all--not even a little bit. The best part of the food was the dessert, only because it was pre-made some where else. I wouldn't take my worst enemy to this place. The first course had no flavor at all like it was done on purpose. Fried shrimp was made so poorly it hurt my soul because I really love food. Second course pork chop reminded me of high school free lunch in terms of breading and flavor . The best part of that was the salad, smh. Just come here for the music that's it.

Smoke Jazz and Supper Club is small cozy spot featuring an array of talented jazz artists nightly.The acoustics are good, tables are very close, soft dim lighting, full bar and decent wine list.There's a ($45) cover charge for the two nightly sets: at 7pm or 9pm, dinner and drinks are extra. The menu is good for a club, consisting of, small portion shrimp cocktail, salads, croquettes, calamari, Beef Brisket, Fish Tacos, Steak, BBQ Spare Ribs, fried Chicken, Salmon, Cajun Lobster Bouillabaisse, Lobster Ravioli, plus a few desserts.There are also late night sets without dinner (some without cover) if you are inclined to stay out after 10:30pm or midnight. We often go with the dinner crowd and have had the pleasure of enjoying the very talented artist, jazz pianist Renée Rosnes quartet, who is amazing!  Tonight we enjoyed a quintet of top local jazz artists who performed in the John Coltrane Festival running during the Christmas and New Year's holiday season - featuring Eric Alexander on sax, Joe Farnsworth on drums, Larry Willis on piano, Steve Turre on trumpet and John Webber on bass. Great times and wonderful tunes! **Make sure you arrive early to get a good table.**

Giving this a 1 star strictly bc while I turned around to greet my friend at the bar, I noticed the bartender taking a sip from my drink (?). 1) It seemed like bartender put minimal effort into procuring the old fashioned (bitters ratio was way off, no syrup) and 2) I get that you mixed the drink but it's strange and uncool to be taking sips from your clients' drinks when you think they're not looking. Why? I don't understand. Anyway, jazz sets were extraordinary. I may have found my favorite jazz pianist, ELEW, out here on a Wednesday night. Come here for the music, not the drinks!

I really enjoyed this club. We came here to from out of town to celebrate a birthday! Pros: Intimate settingGood foodAttentive staffAwesome musicians Reservations are easy on "open table"Use electronic devices to check you in and pay at your table with server.Cons:Cover on the weekends can get priceyStanding outside until your reservation time beginsPeople talking/ quietness can be a little hard to handleFYI: Weekend cover is $40 with a $20 minimum and during the week it's $15. On Saturday at 11:30-12pm no cover but a $20 minimum. After set to stay for more music, you must pay the next cover.
Nice music!! Nice place! Tasty dishes. I enjoyed my evening. If I will be in New York, I will come here one more time. Thank you!

We came here on a Sunday night, and this place was PACKED. The show started at 7PM, so they recommended us to get here from 6:15-6:30PM in order to facilitate ordering dinner before the show started. Well due to some traffic, we ended up arriving at 7:05PM. However, the staff was still friendly and even gave us seats around the red plush couch in the middle of the club. It was perfect because we weren't too close to the stereos, but we could still hear the music well. We looked at the menu and decided to split an entree, because we weren't too hungry. However, the server explained to us that we either must order an entree each or we have to do the 3 course meal. Dismayed, we ordered an entree each - but we were glad that they weren't too large that we would feel extra stuffed. The lobster ravioli was savory, although I wished it had more lobster inside the ravioli pieces. There was probably three or four times as much ravioli as there was to actual lobster. I appreciated how light it was. The pork chop was reminiscent of how my mom used to make a certain type of pork chop, so I enjoyed eating it. The true highlight though was the Nutella cheesecake. I knew New York cheesecake was great, but this was straight up spectacular! It was the best cheesecake I have ever had! The cheesecake was light, airy, and soft. There was a dense core of Nutella in the middle, which paired well with the plentiful amount of cheesecake. To our pleasant surprise, at the bottom of the bowl was some chocolate cake! I was worried this $8.95 cheesecake would mostly be cheesecake, but I was elated to see another NY cheesecake twist at the bottom! What a wonderful way to spend the night of my birthday! It is pricey here, but if you have some money to spend for a grand night out, this is the place to go!

Visited this spot last weekend w/ my girlfriend. Food was overpriced, but tasted good. Cooktail (I ordered a dirty Martini) was very decent. Apperantly, most people come here for jazz. A nice show w/ profeasional musicians.

Food was good, service was good, show was good. However, it is pricey and is not great in my opinion. It's a nice spot for a date, but not sure I would go out of my way to go back. Great for people visiting NYC who would like to have an intimate jazz experience. Place is on the smaller side which does make it cute.

Dinner and jazz at Smoke is a must do experience while visiting NYC. The staff was attentive, the entertainment was like no other and the price reasonable. My husband and I had a 7:30 reservation. We did the 3 course meal....great food. For the price it was a great value considering how expensive other restaurants are in NYC. We enjoyed the music so much we stayed for a second set. Excellent musicians!

First of all, I really appreciate that this place -- who's menu is dominated by dishes meat and dairy -- took the time to create a thoughtful and delicious vegetarian/vegan option. The dish is a whole roasted cauliflower and is one of the better vegan meals I've had in the city, I highly recommend it.The music and intimate ambiance was great when I went. It was all original pieces from the performer, one of the first times she performed these in NYC, so it felt special to hear something new and certainly different from the typical jazz standards. I would recommend it if you are looking to have a special night out high up on the UWS.
Smoke Jazz Club is always on our itinerary for our yearly trip to NYC. Cozy atmosphere, good food, and killer jazz!

Came here on my birthday. The music was so amazing! It was engaging and calming . The environment was very intimate. Great drink options, great food. They had a three course meal menu. Can't wait to go back

Went on Monday night and the music was great! The ambiance was cozy and the service great. Only surprise was the price, they do charge for music on Monday and you have to order the prefix meal. We went on a whim and were just going to share a couple appetizers and drinks but ended up having to buy the whole prefix meal plus $15 for music. So $100 bucks each later, we were headed home. Great music thou! But for us working class peeps it will have to be reserved for special occasions only. Won't be A hang out place for me.

Great venue,spot on service food was carefully prepared and at least four star. The music fantastic Lezlie Henderson a songstress above most I've seen range,delivery and presence among the best. She and her terrific musicians are their every Wednesday, you owe to yourself GO. Price $$$a little  high but special pricing Sunday-Thursday and cheaper seating at the bar make it affordable keeping in mind the intimacy of the space comes with a premium.

The music was good, the review is based on the food and service. The food is mediocre but serviceable, but simply the worst service I've seen. We were there for dinner and show and there was a pre-fixed menu so we ordered everything ahead of time. Our waitress was often late when bringing us our meal, the tables near us were often finishing up before we got our food. And when she wasn't bringing us our food she was nowhere to be found. When we asked another waiter near by, he simply told us our waiter will be with us shortly. As a result, we didn't get our entree until the last song of the set, and when the set had ended, when other people were getting their checks, we still hadn't gotten our dessert even though we ordered the exact same things. Our waitress actually brought us our check before having served us dessert, and when we complained, she brought out the dessert right away - so it's been ready, but she just failed to serve it to us? I mean seriously, I've been to fast food restaurants with better service. At least I get my food on time and get everything I paid fur.

For the price during restaurant week $120 for two ppl with two drinks($45/pp for just food) the food was only ok and the desert was only a bite size sampler so your appetizer and entree come out to $20 and your sampler dessert $10.. not the best deal.  With tip the bill came out to $140 and we felt like we overpaid for an average restaurant.  The music was great and overall good spot minus the prices which don't deliver.

Do not expect much personal space at this establishment, it is claustrophobically SMALL. However, the music here is incredible. Food is "meh". Just take a seat, have a glass of wine, and enjoy the jazz.

Go for a late show and skip the food. For music and atmosphere, Smoke is a solid 8/10. The food, though, is 1/10. I know the food at jazz clubs is never really good, but I've never had any that's actually offensively bad. For vegetarians especially, this is a miss--they have one entree option and it's shriveled and cold, which considering the price ($42 for a prix fixe menu and $38 for an hour show) I found to be unacceptable. The staff also wasn't able to offer any alternates to the single vegetarian dish on the menu. It's fine for a late show with drinks (which were quite good), but for dinner, skip this and check out something cheaper and better in the area like Minton's.

Where do I begin with this place. We just went during restaurant week and the only good part about it was the music and the service. Everything else felt like I was in a super overpriced mediocre tourist trap. This place should consider not participating in restaurant week because the whole point is for people that go during this time to ACTUALLY want to return but I left feeling robbed. The food was the worst part. My husband ate the fried chicken and I had the pork chop.  They were both edible but nothing close to justifying the cost. The dessert included on the restaurant week option was a joke! I had three 1 inch squares of cold brownies and my husband had tiny macaroons. For drinks we ordered a bottle of the house wine. If we wanted some of the better options on their menu for food or dessert there was an up charge. All in all, just to give you an idea we spent $220 before tips which I would have gladly paid if the food wasn't worth $20/$30 at best. With so many awesome options in NYC do yourself a favor and skip this one!

Went here Sunday with a group of 25 for the second brunch session for my sister's birthday and was surprisingly disappointed!! The ambiance is awesome... very homely and cozy and authentic jazz club look. The staff is amazingly welcoming and accommodating especially for our large group. The staff was very attentive but....... the most important aspects of the brunch were mediocre at best (THE FOOD)!!! The menu is limited but diverse enough that everyone can find something. I ordered the chicken and waffles and was to say I went home hungry but by choice. I was offered the option to order something else but my group was finishing up their meals so I opted not to reorder. The waffle was small and loaded with so much sugar it tasted grainy with each bite. The chicken was bland and not fully cooked but on the plus side the portion of 4 pieces would have been welcomed if it had some taste. At least 7 people in my party had to send their chicken back so it wasn't a fluke! Others in my group agreed the waffle was a diabetic shock to the system and theirs were quite a few complaints of the waffle size. The burger was the 2nd item most ordered in our group which seemed to escape complaint. My sister said the salmon was perfectly cooked but definitely lacked flavor. The atmosphere of this place is so adorable but don't go hungry!! Forgot to mention the size of the champagne glass for the mimosa's was a slap in the face for $11. Not even a standard size champagne flute!

Could be considered overpriced and there's often a hefty cover charge, but this is a great place to hear live jazz and really immerse yourself in the music... especially if you are looking for something late at night.

I love some of the music and musicians, some of whom are old friends of mine but this club is over priced and uses false advertisement! They say there's only a $9 minimum but then they have a 2 drink minimum and drinks are about $12 apiece. Add the tip and you'll drop about $30 minimum. Wanna relax and get a burger, count on $50

The experience was ok. Many people praised this place and suggested to visit. So we went to check it out. The club's appearance was ok- definitely not high class but more like a neighborhood club. It was dark inside and the place was tiny. Somewhat, I felt that place wasn't clean enough. The jazz performance was good. However, maybe it was our luck, but the performance was kind of melancholic instead of energizing. It was Friday, so I expected some energy going. Anyway, the musicians were very talented and performed well. The seating costed 38$ each person plus bar order min 15$. I don't know if I would like to come back. Maybe that night wasn't our lucky night lol. I honestly prefer Carlyle hotel, the bemelmans bar.

I feel obliged to write a review for this place bc I had an awesome time when I went there this winter during restaurant week. Venue is rather small and cozy. The music, which lasts about an hour fills the room without being too loud. Talking is discouraged during the set.Food: App: shrimp cocktail (wow, overpriced), onion soup (decent), Entree: salmon and my friend had a seafood dish. Dessert: Peanut butter something. Honestly, the food is nothing to write home about but I thought the salmon was very good. You go to this place for the ambience, music, and its cozy, intimate atmosphere. Well worth the trip to this part of town especially if you are looking to impress or have a good dinner with live music performed by some very talented people:)

Amazing music (The Helen Sung Quartet performed), great ambience, and delicious food (I had the smoked salmon and caviar appetizer). Make reservations in advance as shows usually sell out. Romantic date spot!

Went there for a Jazz and dinner night with a few friends. Definitely a cool atmosphere and the food is decent as well. But more importantly the Jazz artists that play there have never been disappointing (my third time at the place). However, the price is definitely a bit on the higher ends

I was really looking forward to eating and enjoying some jazz here. Our waitress to start - was incredibly rude. I ordered a mojito from the cocktail menu and it a) didn't come in a mojito glass and b) was not worth the price. The salmon appetizer was not fresh and the lobster ravioli was a sad excuse. Jury is still out if the ravioli is frozen or not. The ravioli was buried in red sauce that was not seasoned at all - and complexly masked the taste of any "lobster". The brownie dessert can be compared to something a 10 year old would bake in an Easy Bake Oven. Waste of money. Grab a drink at the bar to enjoy the music. Don't waste money on the food.
The ambiance is quaint & romantic. I recommend the jazzy brunch for the show. The food is good accept my food was cold. Good vibes & experience!

Do I have to even give it a star?  It gets one star for the beautiful and wonderful music. Now for the food...When 2 of our trio arrived we told them that the third was have subway trouble (what else is new). We opted to sit at our table order drinks and wait and told the waiter as much. After getting our drinks about 10 minutes later the waiter asked again and we said our third still hadn't arrived his response: "can't you just put in an order for her?" I got annoyed because they're brunch menu for restaurant week isn't posted online so at that point how would she even know what she wanted. Though we did decide to email her a photo of the menu she ordered and we placed the order. I asked if I could order something on it's own that was available on the rest week brunch menu "truffle onion soup."  And then ordered my meal off the regular menu. The didn't tell me the price but, the soup is $16 on its own! Delicious, but well over-priced. While catching up with my friends and listening to the music the woman "in charge" came over and actually told us to be quiet, while at the same time we looked around and noticed many other tables enjoying themselves and talking with no issues. The meals arrive...or I should say 2 of the meals arrive and the person delivering the food says "I do t have any order for you."  Yup! I ordered chicken and waffles at regular full menu price and they didn't even cook it. I told my friends to enjoy and eat because I didn't want their food to get cold waiting for my food to cook but the guy didn't even come back. I had to flag the rude woman down to find out what was going on. She says they'll cook it. Oh gee thanks! A little while later she comes back and say sorry for the wait your food will be on me. Situation rectified...eh. My food finally comes and it's ok. Not the best chicken and waffles I've ever had...by can you say hangry much. In the meantime, I had to flag the waiter down again to ask for another drink because he didn't bother coming back. He wrapped the remainder of my food and brought the bill. Friends got their desserts which, in my eyes, could have been bigger. My word could you spare some flour? And make the eclair a smidge bigger than a pinky finger. So to the bill, we figure it out and go to pay and what we get charged ends up being more than the bill. I had paid my third but as my friend is paying I ask him what's going on. He says oh I gave you the bill I printed before you ordered the drink. So I ask for the bill (to figure out tax and tip) and he says I will bring it after you pay. I'm trying to tell him we want to put the tip on the cards and he says nope too late to get the correct bill. WTF?  I say ok fine no tip he responds ok well that doesn't just go to me. Hmm if you are the representative for the pooled tip jar then maybe do better at your damn job you fool. I am so frustrated I go to leave as my friends are getting themselves together. Woman again goes to apologize and I explain to her the bill situation. She auto assumes I mean the chicken and tells me I'm wrong. I corrected her in my meaning she makes a face and walks away. Worst service. I won't be back.

My husband and I was walking on Broadway one afternoon and we saw Smoke Jazz Club. We made a reservation for a few weeks later and I am amazed by how great the jazz music was, the food was very good Ambience is excellent. The club is a little small, however if you get there early you can great seats I would recommend this place to anybody that wants great food, and great music!

NYC restaurant week (winter edition)has officially kicked off and me and friends gave this place a try. Well it really was my friends 25th birthday dinner, BUT what a great choice and change of scenery from the normal (brunch, HH, club etc.). We came for the 7pm show which was a great selection of Jazz performance. Great talent! We were a group of 13 and went for the restaurant week pre-fixe menu ($42pp not including tax/gratuity), which was a large selection. I can speak for most of the group everyone was satisfied with their meals.Minor con: -Lobster ravioli was a small portion-Pork chop lacked seasoning-Rose Sangria watered downOverall, great experience for trying something new and good deal. I would recommend for a chill date night. Being the live music it  cuts conversation down to a minimum.

A small gem with lots of charm!I enjoyed the jazz music and the slight romantic vibe. The food is actually is decent. The portions are LARGE! I was full after my appetizer and ended up having to take my entree home. There is a prefixed menu which makes ordering easy and quick. The drinks were classic, nothing spectacular, but well made. Would definitely recommend if you're in the city looking for a nice jazz spot. It's a little far for a Brooklyn girl.

Very nice jazz place. Similar to other reviewers, I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of food. All dishes were legit.The almost-10-dollar bottle of water that comes without your consent is a classic shady move and is of course rarely appreciated by New Yorkers who are just fine with the tap. I see other people complain about this too so I'm not sure why the place would continue with this questionable practice. -1 point for that.Vincent Herring quartet was spectacular. I would suggest not to sit right by the stage. You'll be in the center of commotion with waiters walking around and people coming onto the stage to play.

This is the #1 Jazz Bar I have ever been too. The jazz players are amazing , it's quaint , romantic, laid back, dress up or casual . It's just the perfect little jazz spot in New York City. It's gets packed so call ahead .

My parents drove from Chicago and I booked reservations because of the great jazz music and the brunch menu. The usual singer Anita was not there, and the items that both my parents and I wanted to order, they ran out of! A popular restaurant running out of food-- how does that work? No chicken & waffles, no sea bass, and no more bagels for the salmon platter and my dad ended up having to order yogurt & granola. The food was just okay, besides the fact that we couldn't order what I really wanted. My parents didn't drive 12 hours all the way from Chicago for their first brunch day to be a fail. 2 stars is the best I can do because even though the usual singer wasn't here today, her replacement Jackie Jones and her pianist and drummer were pretty good. I would have gotten up and kindly walked my parents out to find some other place.

Smoke is all about the music.  Had great seats as they are all up close and personnal.  Stage is very small but the music is very large.  Attended Saturday night and couldn't have enjoyed the performers more and we go to many jazz venues.  However, then there is the food for which you must purchase an entree.  Ordered the fried chicken and inquired about white meat and told that the meat was mixed.  Okay I thought but two thighs and two legs were delivered in a basket with NO white meat. Would have preferred a plate to use a knife and fork on. Come on it is a nice and pricey night out. Love collards and the two forkfuls in a small cermaic dish at the bottom of the basket were very good but very, mind you, very small serving.  My meal was a wash.  His was the lobster/scallop hand rolled ravioli in vodkah sauce. Flavorless in all regards not enjoyed.  Skip that entree.  Cocktails and wine choices were very good.  Service slow at our side of the club and our server wasn't very visable thoughout the night although we saw others moving about.  Remember it's all about the jazz and the music will never disappoint even if the food does.

Our experience of Smoke was great. It's a tiny place, even smaller than the photos show. But that's what makes it so great. We got there early and managed to sit right up front. We were practically on stage. We read the instructions carefully so we knew what to expect in terms of fees and the $38 prix fixe on weekends. The best deal is the weekday as it's only $9 per person for the fee. For the prix fixe, everything on the menu is on offer but there's a supplement charge if you want one of the more expensive dishes. I was pleasantly surprised to find the food excellent. I wasn't sure if this would be the kind of place where the music is great but the food is average. We had the French onion soup, beef short ribs and steak. My short ribs were excellent. It came in a cast iron dish nestled with mashed potatoes, collards, pearl onions and a rich brown gravy. My partner's NY strip steak wasn't the best cut despite the price. It was huge but he was disappointed with the overall cut and taste.The show was great and I was impressed with the caliber of talent. After the set, they had a Monday jam session where amateurs can come and play. It was a nice extra though you could tell a big difference in quality. All in all, a nice evening out to hear some jazz.

This place seems to be for lovers. I came here on a Thursday night for a late dinner with my homegirl and we must have been the only twosome that was not here on a date. We have OpenTable reservations and were able to waive the music charge because we were there for NYC restaurant week.The food was solid. Everything tastes as it should. I enjoyed the calamari the best which was paired with a tasty mayo sauce. The Mac & cheese was nothing special. The dessert was also quite good but the most memorable part of the dining experience was the Latin Jazz band that was performing. As a result of the tight space, the volume was louder than I would like but completely entertaining.No complaints about the food or service so I would definitely see myself coming back to star lovingly into Babes' eyes as the jazz  tunes envelope us...

Went to Smoke last Thursday and was pleasantly surprised! The band was The Akie Bermiss Quartet and WOW! Did they SWANG!!Had the chicken dish with potato and carrots and a glass of wine. Foods were yummy...music was SUBLIME!Bring these folks back IMMEDIATELY!!

Ahh New York, the city of great jazz music. Well, you got a lot of that here at Smoke. However, everything else at this bar was sub par at best.I know we're in NYC, but damn, everything was so cramped up in here I was bumping into everyone when I was getting from one side of the room to the other. Plus, the people here were very rude to the musicians. I know I shouldn't hold that against the establishment, but I just thought I'd let that out there.The minimum payment of $20 was a bit much for a short jazz show. Cocktail menu was nice but the beer list was rather short. They serve food here which looked delicious, but i did not try it unfortunately.Honestly though, check out Smoke if you love jazz music. I think they got music playing for the majority of the week there, with jam sessions and open mics.
Sunday brunch at the Smoke is a real jazz experience. Amazing music and good quality food

Really great food and atmoshpere. The live Jazz music is awesome. They have a really good restaurant week deal. Big menu with lots of choices and no cover mon-thurs. I came here for restaraunt week and definitely want to come back again. Went on a Wednesday night at 830 and it was packed, had a reservation so it was fine. The jazz singer was amazing and so was the band. I got the fried oysters appetizer which is small but delicious. And the salmon for dinner which was surprisingly filling. My friend got the short ribs, wish I got that- I stole a bite and it was so succulent and rich. The desserts are very sweet. The cheesecake is fluffy and had a hint of vanilla which I like and had a nutella center. The peanut butter chocolate pie is more like a giant reeses peanut butter cup. It was very rich and sweet and between me and my friend we only ate half of it. Great experience I recommend!!!
Love the joint and blackened catfish, but damn it is expensive and rushed as per set rules prevail despite waits.

Came on a Sunday for brunch with a girlfriend, we loved the food and vibes! The singer had a great stage presence and we all clapped along with her during our meal. I noticed some other customers weren't even talking to each other during their meal because they were just too busy enjoying the music. I like that it was great even for families, some of the kids really enjoyed the show too. I'm seeing in some other reviews that people had to pay for the show and were required to spend a certain amount for their meal...was not the case for us, perhaps because it was brunch.About the food:* Free bread - the banana muffins weren't bad, but I really liked the brioche with whatever sauce was on it already + orange jam (the server called it a syrup...), but beware you might get too full* Chicken and waffles, $18.95 - I loved the syrup, but chicken was a bit too crispy. I also would have preferred other parts of the chicken with less bone so I didn't have to use my hands and could actually eat it with the waffle. At least the waffle was on point.* Smoked salmon, $16.95 - I like that the salmon wasn't smoked too much that it overwhelms you and the bagel wasn't crispy. Conveniently how I like it when my friend's preferences were opposite haha. Tasted great with the cream cheese and arugula salad. Only thing I did not like about our experience was getting the bill and being surprised by the $10 charge for still water. I think we had trouble understanding the server's accent when she asked us if we wanted water, and I noticed a couple other tables almost had the same thing happen to them. A good surprise was finishing the meal pretty quickly for a Sunday brunch because service was quick.
Overpriced average food. Friday night music was an additional $40/person charge. Music was great but the food was a let down. Go for the music but dont expect a great meal.

Do not go to Smoke Jazz and Supper Club for dinner. The food is overpriced and horrible. They charge a $38 music fee per person and require everyone to order a $30 entree. The only reason to go to this place is for the music so do you're self a favor and sit at the bar and spare yourself the dining experience. The food was on par with airplane food. This "restaurant" would be better off as a bar.The music was decent, but not worth the expense.

Excellent jazz and a great meal. The venue is small but that makes it really cozy. The music is great and the food and drinks are really good. The one draw back is that because it is so small you sit really close to others and if they don't have good music manners you are in trouble. Other than that this is going to be my new favorite Jazz place for a fun night out and a delicious meal.

Booked a reservation at Smoke. Lezlie Harrison was performing on a Wednesday night. Have to say the music, food, and overall ambience was superb. Her singing just moves you as the love and talent she has just shines. Hubby and I were impressed with the service as well. Definitely would come back..

Kitchen is super slooow. Way over 30 min and our salads haven't even shown up. The food is going to have to be spectacular to raise this crowded sight-line-challenged place above two stars. The wine is ok. So far, not so great. The arugula salad is bitter. It's not baby arugula, and the few bits of flavorless pomegranate and canned tangerine and aren't enough to offset the bitterness. The salad also had some tasteless white slices of either endive or celery root. The three of us who had the salads as an app quit after eating less than half. I'll talk about the steak if it ever shows up... Ooh! It's here! Ok. The steak has a good smokey taste, but it's barely warm. Granted I ordered it rare, but if you get a rare steak to the customer right away, it should still be nice and warm. Especially on the outside. It's also too fatty. And we're now halfway through the music set because the food came so slowly, so no time to send it back. The music was good. And it sounded good. And that's the reason to come here, so three stars. Now we're home. I had some sorbet and my wife heated up a frozen dinner for herself.

Decent place to see some solid jazz music.  The night we were there, Jim Rotondi, David Hazeltine and Joe Locke were amazing. The food is actually pretty good. I enjoyed the short rib, and my wife was happy with the pork chop.  It is a bit on the pricey side, especially considering the cost of the tickets. And while they offer a prix fixe menu on select nights, it seems every other entree and dessert involves an upcharge on top of that. Service got off to a slow start--it seemed only one server was working, but soon others filled in and the rest of the evening, service was very good. Like some NYC jazz clubs, the restaurant really packs the chairs in so it can tight to get in and out of tables, and they place tables immediately adjacent to the band, which is also a little too cozy. I also didn't like that most of the tables were set perpendicular to the band, so most of the audience is either forced to look left or right to watch the band, which isn't exactly the most comfortable position. This place isn't quite as bad as Blue Note, but there are more comfortable spots to see fine jazz in the city.  My advice: Arrive early for your show to get a more desirable seat.

I chose this place based on reviews and i was disappointed about the food. While they had a prix fixe menu so options were there for a bargain, the food was not so good. I ordered steak medium well and it came well done and it was dry. So was my date's salmon. French fries were decent but you should get what you paid for. Music was good the live band aspect part is worth it.

This is probably the worst place ive ever been to in my life! I come from a third world country honestly, even there, the shittiest place, is a 5 star plus compared to that place!! NO GO folks, trust me its sooo bad... The setting, the food, the music and even the waiters, are wayyy below average!!!

I came here with my husband and it was a great time. The food wasn't too impressive however the reason that I gave it only three stars is because the establishment is not that big, among a few small personal preferences. The live music was awesome. The seating is very close in quarters. There is no privacy if you are looking for an intimate setting. The drinks are small and expensive.
Came here post-yoga with a friend, such a great spot to wind down with some eats and cocktails. Prices weren't bad, music was great! And I had a celebrity sighting, so that's always fun!

Great live music. The only downfall is that it's a total bait and switch with the prix fix dinner (some items require additional cost) $8 more for Foie Gras which they ran out of$2 more for Shrimp cocktail it was only 4 per serving.$38 prix fix dinner AND an additional $38 pp for the music. Food is mediocre.I would hate to get charged an extra $8 for cannoli the size of a Vienna sausage.I wouldn't recommend this place just for the sake for live music. Usually if you pay for live music it last at least an hour. They only played for 45 minutes and require you to a $20 minimum additional if you stay for the next set. Better of going somewhere they don't charge for live music. Like Jule's in the LES

Classic, intimate jazz scene with lovely food! We went to the late seating and stayed for the midnight music. Very enjoyable atmosphere. Go to enjoy the NYC jazz- We saw Lezlie Harrison   and band's first night at Smoke and it was very good. Later on, Mel Davis and his band played a long set. Top notch musicians, top notch performers. The mix of the lovely B3 organ and the guitarrist's choice of wacky cool sounds (70s progressive rock, etc.) cracked me up!  Make reservations because it is not a large venue. If you haven't been there- get there! I'll be back next time we're in town. (Only slight drawback was the "pink lemonade"-- a little weak and uninteresting).
Tried to make reservations but unable to on website. The manager/ owner (?) Was very accommodating and set us up off to the side. Music was great, food was good. Will definitely be back.

Went here last night with a group of four. The wait staff was beyond wonderful.... So attentive. Fish tacos were out of this world and generous portions.  Thought the price fixe dessert was pretty sparse.. could've used some chocolate on the plate.  The music was unparalleled jazz.. Ralph Moore on the saxophone can't be beat. Wonderful place to hear music in the city.

The Jazz at Smoke's was slamming. The band lead by Champion Fulton was spectacular, her voice was that of an angel and her skill with the piano was underpasses. The food at Smoke's is always good and you won't go hungry. I check it out at least twice a month and have never been disappointed.

Wanted to give them a 3.5 due to the following reasons: 1. Drinks- pricey and served in small glasses (6 oz) 2. Food- small portions with high cost. This isn't a 5 star restaurant. However the Calamari, French onion soup, braised short ribs and lobster ravioli were well prepared 3. Sitting- tight no privacy and first come first serve 4. The environment overall is pleasant and welcoming 5. Performers get an A++ just sucks the pole on stage blocks some of the viewWe do recommend for anyone to try and enjoy a good time!

It was a nice experience, but the service was pretty bad. Our waters were never filled unless they came to refill or neighbors water, not sure if we didn't fit in with their general crowd. My first drink order, the elder flower Bellini had a bug in it. I didn't want to make a big deal, so a scoped it out and tried to give them another chance. Then the chicken and waffles were so over cooked, I could barely bite into the chicken. Felt like I was going to break my teeth. My second drink was a bloody Mary that was watered down with no olive. The music was good, but I don't think I'll return for bad food, drinks and service.

Came for my birthday, which was also during Restaurant Week. Lots of places kinda drop the ball during Restaurant Week, so maybe that was the case here? But I'm inclined to say that food quality issues go deeper than just a high volume/low cost special.Service was awkward and slow (no refills, rounds, or waters unless they were specifically asked for). Also, the people next to us were loud, and a third person joined them at their 2 person table halfway through the show (so basically squeezed in at our table) but the servers/bouncers never did anything about this.Shrimp cocktail was a little sketchy, and consisted of 4 shrimp. The chicken I ordered came out in a cast iron dish like it had been roasted in it, but the dish itself was ice cold? So it was a fake "roasted" dish! The chicken itself was super dry and almost inedible. My boyfriend had a steak, ordered medium rare, that came out well-done and so fatty that he (not a picky eater!) also couldn't eat his meal. My mom had the fish tacos, and frankly they were the only edible thing on the table, though they were super plain fried fish tacos. Finally, dessert was actually humorous-- a creme brulee that had not been bruleed, strangely bland cannolis, and a peanut butter chocolate pie that tasted like "dirt with a hint of nuttiness", and everyone at the table had one bite before it was pushed aside. Honestly, peanut butter chocolate pie! How can it be bad?!?!The music is good, and the atmosphere is swanky and nostalgic. That's it. Maybe if you've got the extra cash (since it's pretty pricey to pay for both a show + a two item minimum, where wine and cocktails are easily $13/each), it'd be worth coming in for a few drinks at the bar while listening to some jazz. But whatever you do, do not eat here.

Went for restaurant week and did the brunch special. Great deal. The food was good considering it's sort of tough to get like 40 plates out at one time for a show. Very much enjoyed my waffles, though I was in a sugar coma for a good part of the day afterwards. Go for the experience and the music, the food is sort of secondary.

Jazz was great, can't fault that, but the rest of the evening was pretty poor.  To start, the waitress was clearly otherwise pre-engaged with who knows what.  She brought the wrong drinks to the table, brought the wrong menus (changed them only after being prompted), didn't take a food order for a good 40 minutes.  Starter was relatively quick, but was just about big enough for a 7 year old.  Mains didn't come out until well over an hour after the starters had been cleared.  And when they did, they were tasteless.  The salad was far more interesting that the breaded pork cutlet it was served on top of.  The lobster ravioli itself was nice enough, but the sauce was completely tasteless. Luckily we had the jazz to keep us entertained.  But for near $300 for a meal for two and wine, a 3 hour sit down, and pretty poor food, I may of well hosted a party for the superbowl.  If you're going to have such a long wait and you know it, tell your customers and offer a free round or two.  For this price tag, I'd expect a lot more..
Y'all the barman Tarik Osman makes the best cosmopolitan in town seriously I'm living for this cocktail tonight!?

Went to Smoke Jazz to celebrate my wedding anniversary and I am so glad we did! The ambiance was nice and romantic.  The jazz was nice and mellow and at a good volume. The food was very good! They were able to accommodate my various food allergies without jeopardizing the taste and quality.  We will definitely be going back.

Went for restaurant week. Waaay overpriced for what it was. The ambiance was nice (the place is very small) and jazz was fantastic, but the food was just ok. Also the music cover is $38 per person for about 5 songs, to me it wasn't worth it. Nothing to write home about.

The place was nice. In my opinion it felt small. They tried to fit too much in a small space. I liked the idea of it being a Jazz club and having live music. The night I went the music was okay. The service was okay as well. The alcoholic drinks offered I tried 2 of them and I didn't like it and had to resort to white dessert wine which came in a tiny wine glass yet cost more than 15 dollars  .  Overall the place was okay. I would suggest people to go. Just because I said it was okay others may really like it. I don't know that I would return.

It's a nice way to spend a night when you love live music.  Something different to do, but nothing about the actual place was very good. The food was kind of terrible (tacos, calamari, scallop/lobster ravioli, cannoli) and both of our mixed drinks were so poor that despite being $12 a piece we opted to not drink them and get wine instead.  We spent about $200 all in and the atmosphere and overall night was fine, but it was not a great experience and I don't imagine we'll be back.  It wouldn't be fair to judge on one performer because the music is always different. Overall, still maybe go once. Just either sit at the bar so that you don't pay the $38 per person plus tickets minimum and just order wine - or choose to enjoy the music and have a nice (though cramped) table, but don't expect anything from the food.

Most excellent exquisite dishes (a surprise in a jazz club). See the pictures. Very pricey. So please be prepared. Jazz doesn't happen to be the soft kind to my liking, but that is just personal. Good, attentive fast service. Nice decor. Very tight space, and noise level definitely too loud. With the band playing we could not hear each other. Could not chat. Could not place an order (waiter couldn't hear a word). That is the only draw back.
This place left my girlfriend and I speechless. The music, drinks, and desserts were amazing. The staff was very welcoming and attentive. The lighting and sound was perfect. Would highly recommend.

I loved the intimate venue, the band, the breaded pork with arugula salad and mac&cheese. Wine list is a pricey selection but we went for it. Forewarning: They ask you to whisper during the musical sets and not to use flash photography. You can't linger after the set either, they clear everyone out for the next set of reservations to take the tables.

Band that played was really good but $40/person is a bit much for the 1hr show. Food was overly priced for the quality. I had ordered the fried oysters. Over cooked and the shells laid on a bed of salt. I couldn't tell since it blended with the plate until I tasted it. Pork cutlet and steak was over cooked. I asked for medium rare but I got well done instead. When I complained waiter said it'll be a long wait. The dining tables are so close and cramped. No privacy. It was hard to see the band when the tables are so close and the person next to you keeps moving  or is huge. When paying for dinner my card was denied. When I called my bank they said it had been charged huge sums at the same place that it locked my account.I wouldn't recommend.

Be careful and check your bill at the end. They say that if you are dining btwn 6-10pm it is considered a dinner reservation and you don't have to buy tickets for the show. At the end of the dinner (8pm dinner reservations)  - after which we were required to order an entree, which was fine - our bill had two 38.00/each charges for the live music viewing.  The manager argued with me when I brought it to his attention. So my question: what then is the point of requiring us to buy an entree AND charging the music fee, even though it says otherwise on the restaurant on Open Table. Not cool.

This is a consistent neighborhood go to of mine. Delicious food, cozy ambiance and swinging jazz!!! Paul and Frank have been the friendly long time owners of this jazz spot and are staples of the upper west side. They are always there to say hello and greet you at the door. This is one of the amazing small businesses left in NYC, let's keep it alive!

I planned a birthday dinner outing here for my mom's birthday. A lover of jazz, she was surprised and thrilled to be here for her birthday dinner. The place is on the small side but, that aside...it's a fantastic venue. We were slated to see one show and have dinner, because it was my mom's birthday (I told them when I made the reservation), we were invited to stay for the 2nd show as well. We did and were very glad about it. The band was fabulous (Joe Chambers did his thing!) and the food was great. In all, it was a great night out and I'll definitely be back.

This not a review about the food, ambiance or the music as they were all great.This review is about the management. They are awful. I ordered tickets ahead of time in order to secure a table for my party. When the night ended and the check came out - I thought it seemed a bit high but OK. After leaving and further review - I realized that I was charged for the tickets twice: once to reserve and again on the dinner bill. After emailing and contacting Smoke Jazz for over a month, I was either given the runaround or simply not responded to. Save yourself the pain of a subpar staff and management team and spend your money and time elsewhere.

Cute, cozy, fun place.  Wonderful music. Really good food. Mixed drinks were... mixed.  Bloody Mary was watery, wrong mouth feel and not recommended. Other drinks were better but not their strong suit.  Nice decor; not stiff not too elegant, fun and cozy feel.  On the brunch menu, Chicken and Waffles are highly recommended!
A must go for a jazz night in a cosy atmosphere. Musicians are literally at a touching distance. The dinner is a 3 course fixed price menu at 38usd.

Musicians are great in this place. Live music with dinner makes an amazing moment. If you are looking for some place to make a special experience, I would like to recommend this place. Space is a little bit small, but that is okay. Feel special!

Came here with out of town guests, last min, no res, on a Saturday night. And was able to get into the late night show that started around 12pm with four people at a table! SCORE! Great music, okay drinks. Only downside is we missed the kitchen. So while on their menu outside it says dinner from XX-2am... that's not really true. Didn't give 5 stars, because I really wanted the french onion soup. Only the hungry yelper's will understand me... =*( *if you come, please don't carry conversations. What you think is fun for your party, is actually rude and disruptive to the artist and other guests trying to enjoy the ambience.  If you want to have a conversation go to a bar. If you want to enjoy music, come here!

I honestly used to love to come here. Now, there are far too many rules. There's a minimum noise level, which I get. But no talking? One person in our group spoke above a whisper and the host was very rude in the way she told us to tone it down.They also had minimum of one entree per guest. We already paid $40 admission, now they expected us to pay for an entree whether we wanted one or not.I get that it's a nice place, but the acts aren't always that great and it isn't fun or relaxing. I kind of felt bad for bringing my friends here.
One of the best venues to listen to live jazz in the city, it is on the small side and you will not be able to have a conversation but that's not the reason you came here in the first place!

Small, intimate club on street level, not in a basement! Jazz was amazing, great acoustics. The food was also a big surprise - I am a foodie, and the lemon chicken entree was so incredibly delicious, served with baby carrots, spinach and mashed potatoes. And, here's the surprise, ORGANIC chicken!!! As a foodie, this is what I buy for myself, I'm a Whole Foods market organic grocery shopper. It was elegantly prepared and presented, and tasted delicious. I was actually blown away by this meal, as jazz clubs typically serve food which is OK, this was hands down better than many 5-star meals I have had. Props to the kitchen. I visited on Saturday night, 8/20/2016 for the 10:30 show. One star off due to the bathroom door being right next to the stage (there is only one small bathroom). Every time this door opens, you have a view of the toilet. Not ideal, but the amazing kitchen staff and food make up for it!
Absolutely amazing... Wonderful food wonderful music. Definitely different from other noisy so called "Jazz Bar". Restaurant week is definitely a good deal!! Best idea for dates.

Came for restaurant week. They have a minimum noise policy because of the band. The jazz band played super loudly. Like there's no way to converse. You're pretty much forced to listen to the music that's blaring into your face. I thought it'd be soft jazz playing in the corner, not like a jazz show that also serves dinner. It was at Rock and roll/metal loudness. Maybe I'd feel differently if I LOVED jazz. This place, you'd really have to LOVE jazz. You come here for the music and the band and you just happen to have dinner while watching the band. This is not a dinner place with music in the background, which is what I was expecting. I don't mind jazz; I just don't want it screaming at me while I'm trying to have dinner. Definitely disappointed with that aspect.In terms of food, not great. Calamari was nothing special. The lobster ravioli smelled very strange/fishy and tasted tangy. The smore's brownie tasted store-bought. Not impressed.
Came here with my dad. Booked reservations ahead of time. Music was great! Food was great, too, but on the pricey side.

Had a great time...Small quaint place, food was good (nice portions), decent menu options since it was Restaurant week. But the EXTRA $45 PER person for the "dinner show" was a little outrageous.  The band was good (and my parents enjoyed it) so I'm not opposed to paying for the entertainment. It just made a dinner for 4 = $415 :-(
I've been here many times over the years. One of New York's best date places...ambiance, music and food are all great. Highly recommended even for non-jazz lovers.
Came here for restaurant week, food was amazing, service was also good, two things I did not like jazz music was very loud for such small restaurant and AC was not working properly

I can't breathe in this place. The food was OK aside from my Dad's raw salmon. The music was fine but loud. Air doesn't work. Drinks are room temp. Let's just second Andrey on this one. Dessert hasn't come yet. Dessert hasn't come yet. We'll see about the birthday cake. Have a feeling I'm going to pass.... If I don't pass out first.

Well, straight  to the point:1.Food is amazing...2.Three air-conditioning  units don't work properly....3.Draft beer was room temperature(((((4. And the last: Live Juzz music was extremely loud...and too fast......5. Wait staff....very nice and polite.

The lamb sliders here are fantastic. I would give this place five stars for those alone. However, it must be noted that the music here is very loud. I guess that's expected because it's live music, but the music is deafeningly loud in there and it gets a little unpleasant after a while.

I love music.I love the vibe of this place.The drinks are strong enough.The food is tasty, though not exceptional.The prices, though, are ridiculous. Bring your first born's birth certificate along with any extra arms and legs you can part with. They pretty much want it all.But usually the music is good, so that's a plus.

Came here for a date night and had an incredible time. There is a $38 cover per person, however, given the talent of the performers and the incredible ambiance of the club, it was worth every penny. They have a great drink selection, with cocktails starting at $11. We also ordered a couple of appetizers which were tasty. All-in-all a wonderful night! Will definitely be back again!
Small, but fun, with good sound, good music, and good (albeit overpriced) food. Smoke is an uptown staple for jazz, at a time when few good uptown jazz clubs still exist.

A refreshing alternative to the usual boozy brunch. Smoke Jazz Club is a must try for Jazz lovers looking for good food and live music. The space encourages a more intimate interaction with the band and allows for a more personal experience. The lovely singer even greeted my boyfriend a "Happy Birthday" from the stage. My boyfriend ordered the Belgian Waffles with bacon, pecans, strawberries, and maple syrup. I opted for the Eggs Benedict over english muffin, topped with Canadian bacon and hollandaise, with a side of tater tots and organic baby green salad. The portions were filling. Both were good but I wouldn't say great. The live band experience definitely outweighs the quality of the food. I wouldn't recommend coming here if you're looking to catch up with company. The restaurant does ask that you respect the performers and keep chatter to a minimum. All in all, pricier than your usual brunch menu but worth the show.

Came to smoke for something other than a bar in New York City... It was great! The performer that night did an awesome job of keeping the crowd paying attention and feeling good. The food was very expensive which we had none of so I don't know if it was worth the price. They have a long drink menu. All sorts of beers, wine, cider, and champagne. They have all the normal liquors. It wasn't too expensive but it did cost 9$ a beer. Overall great atmosphere and fun place to be on the upper west side !

Set out with my roommate for a different kind of bar experience and ended up in Smoke. We loved it! The space was very cozy and it was relaxing just sitting at the bar and listening to the band on stage (who were very good, by the way). They have a bar but also a space directly in front of the stage for sit down dining. There is a $12 cover for sitting at the bar and then you can't spend less than $20 for food and drink. We decided to stick to drinking, since the food looked very expensive ($25 for a burger, what?). I believe there is also a cover and some other rules about sitting at the tables, so it would be good to find out before you go in. I also wouldn't come here in a large group or if you have the intention of catching up or talking with people. They ask that you respect the bands on stage and stay quiet while they perform, so there isn't a lot of conversation going on (also because it would be hard to do above the music).
The only reason I gave four is the prices. Expensive. Also, drinks are small, small glasses. OtherwisE, nice classy crowd, great music, service, and food.

Came here for Sunday brunch !! The live jazz was amazing !! Good alternative to the loud tiring boozy brunch, this was very nice and relaxing. Ambiance was perfect. Now on to the food, I ordered the breakfast pizza, wasn't really a fan, I asked for feta cheese on my pizza and was brought out without, the crust was a bit too crisp for me almost a bit burned, the bacon was almost not there, this was basically just thin pizza toast with fried egg on it, others with me had the chicken and waffles and they had no complaints I suggest you stay away from the breakfast pizza and opt for something else.My 4 stars is simply on the ambiance, and entertainment! Service was alright nothing crazy nothing major lacking but also no wow factor. Come for the Jazz stay for the Jazz !!

AMAZING! Staff super nice! The band is awesome! The singer was so sweet and talented !! The food is delicious too!! You have to try it :) I came for brunch on Sunday , it was my birthday and as soon as the staff ( and my lovely waitress) heard about it , they surprise me with a wonderful brownie dessert with a candle ! Something happen with my group ( a lot of them couldn't make it) and they totally understood . I will be back!!

Came here for a Monday night date. This place is fantastic, with classy atmosphere. We came here for a 7pm show. I recommend coming here at least half an hour before the show starts, so that you can order and settle down before the music starts. The food was medicore but large portions. We both ordered prix fixe. I ordered the salmon and my date ordered the steak. I kind of expected the food to be medicore, so I was happy with it. Nevertheless, awesome place for music and food.
Good customer service and ambience. Food could use some help with flavoring and drinks are a bit weak. Would have given 4 stars if it wasn't so pricy.

Really love this place. I'm never a fan of the jazz club formula where you're sat, rushed through dinner and given a bill to force you out for the next seating. Do I understand that jazz clubs might have limited opportunities to make their money in a short amount of time? Perhaps....or that patrons might take advantage and sit all night with one drink in-hand. I get it. Therefore I do recommend hitting the 9pm show for Prix Fixe dinner $38. Weekdays only I believe - Tuesday night's are my go to. If you sit through the 9pm typically you can stay at your table or the bar seating without being bothered and you'll cruise through the 1030pm performance. If you're feeling like pulling a late night, some of the younger acts that jump on stage at midnight have been really talented and you get a glimpse of the next generation of jazz to come. Great stuff. Since I'm a local, this is my spot, and for sure recommend it as long as you're doing the 9pm dinner show or after. Catfish was decent, the Brussel sprouts needed some kick, and the chocolate brownie dessert needed more marshmallow. You're going for the music :)

A quality experience! The Jazz for the most part is at a very high level here. The food is decent as well. They do have a reasonable prix fixe for under 40 dollars. The bartenders mix great cocktails here. Would recommend the Sidecar and the Dark and Stormy here. After 1130 on most nights, there is no extra musical cover charge, just a 20 dollar drink/food minimum. Some of the headlines that have played here are true alltime legends - Gary Bartz, Eddie Henderson, and Bob Cranshaw. My favorite House bands that play the Round Midnight sessions include William Delisfort, Johnny O'Neill, and Captain Black's Big Band. They even have a Hip Hop inspired after hours session led by Nickel and Dine Ops on Thursdays nights that is quite good. The only after hours evening that doesn't quite measure up is the Tuesday Night session done by the Emmet Cohen Trio. They're talented but I didn't feel they gave proper respect to the art form. I noticed the trumpet player for that trio texting while on stage, not cool.Overall though a great experience on most nights!

If the 1 train decides to work on weekends, I'm hitting this place up more often. Real reaaaaaaaaaaaal high up on the island, this place is a fun Saturday/Sunday afternoon activity. I met up with some friends on a Sunday afternoon, some ordered food/drinks all were brunch themed type menu items at around 2pm. The favorite seemed to be the fruit/granola bowl (HUGE) and the steak/chicken tacos. The jazz singer was amazing..can't believe how talented she was, as well as the jazz band. These people are worth coming up this high for.The place itself is really nice, big cushy booths, great for hanging out and listening to music. The only downside was the service, a little spacey. Forgot to place some food orders and had to keep flagging down to get a refill on water even though the place was barely half full :/.
Great place! Small, intimate with amazing music and food! The staff was friendly and the service was good! The braised short ribs and vegetables were delicious.  Highly recommend going there.

Jazz was great. Wine was good for the price. The food was terrible at best. Worst fried chicken I've ever had. $38 per person cover charge is ridiculous for an hour of music. Go somewhere else for dinner and come for jazz and drinks assuming you are ok with the cover.
This is one of the last remaining jazz brunch restaurants in the city. It is really Amazing with live great Music and delicious Food.

Went here for restaurant week winter 2016. Arrived around 7:00PM, which was just in time to see the live jazz band, and they were really good! I had the honey fried chicken, and my bf had the buffalo wild wings and lemon chicken. I could definitely taste the honey in the fried chicken, but I didn't particularly like the aftertaste (it was kind of like when you have artificial sweetener). Giving it three stars because the food was subpar, but the band was good.

This place was fantastic! The management was so attentive - I made a little note in my reservation through Open Table that we were celebrating a special occasion and the manager kept passing by to make sure we were all set! The waiters were great at explaining the menu items and how the dinner + show prix fixe dinner worked. The show and ambience were perfect - it was inch a great dining and entertainment experience. What a great gem on the upper west side.Food: 4.5/5 honestly flavor wise the meals were great. I had the lemon chicken and my boyfriend had the steak. The only reason it's not 5/5 is that they meats were a tiny bit dry. For The steak entree we subbed the truffle fries for regular and they were nice and crispy. For the chicken entree, the mashed potatoes were amazing and the carrots and spinach tasted so fresh. We also tried the Brussel sprouts and those were cooked to perfection. The dessert brownie was delicious, a little dense and it could use some ice cream along with it, but I prefer everything a la mode.

Trying to understand why people rate this so highly. The ONLY good part was the music itself. The service was very slow. The food was cold- My burger was well done when I ordered Medium Rare, we were shushed more than once. The hostess was really, really rude and aggressively hostile. It really is a shame-

This music was divine  The food was very fulfilling It is small, but that's what makes it so wonderful for something like a date night! I ordered the steak, and I was not disappointed. The service is so wonderful Strongly recommended

The show was extremely short for what we paid for. This is not a social jazz club like i thought...you know with jazz playing in the background and you and your date are listening at some parts and talking at other parts. No. We got shushed...twice...for talking at all. Our bad..we didn't know! We were disappointed with the overall experience but it's really because this wasn't our scene. We just had drinks here so can't review the food.

It was my friend's first time visiting NYC and he requested we go to a jazz club. I made reservations 3 weeks in advance for dinner/show at Smoke Jazz Club because of all the good reviews the place had. When we arrived at 915pm for a 930 reservation, the previous show was not finished yet and we were told to wait outside on the left side. The people waiting on the right side were those who did not have reservations. By 10pm we were still waiting outside to be seated and the host had let in everyone without reservations before us. When our table was finally ready, we were sat in the farthest 2 corner tables in the bar area! I mentioned this to the owner that I was displease with our seats and he just brushed me off saying there are no bad seats in the club (I beg to differ).Granted the space is intimate and small, I had to practically stand on my chair in order to see the band. I'm giving this place still 3 stars because the music by Jim Snidero was amazing and the food was decent. If this establishment were to fix their customer service and cater more to those with reservations then those without, they would receive a better rating.

Small, but nearly perfect. Amazing music. 4.5 stars.Smoke Jazz is small. Really, really small. Even by NYC standards small. There are chain restaurants in the mid-west that have bathrooms larger than this place. The whole place is - and I'm not exaggerating - about the size of a suburban living room. To pay the bills, they pack in guests like sardines, in two narrows rows of tables plus some seats at the bar. There's room for maybe 50-60, all elbow-to-elbow. The only place that's packed in tighter is economy class seating on an airliner.It's definitely not for the claustrophobic, or even those who have issues about personal space. You'll need to coordinate with your neighbor to turn your seat to face the stage.The good new is that a small space is, almost by definition, an intimate space. Even the tables in the very back are great seats, and the front table are so close you could play the instruments yourself. For several reasons, this makes Smoke a great place to experience live jazz.For starters, it sounds great. The acoustics are great, and the sounds system, which might not even be needed, is setup well enough that's it's basically transparent. From such a close distance, you can also get a real sense of just how talented these guys on stage are. We attended the Saturday night show of the Russell Malone Quartet. Watching him play guitar is like watching a magician - his fingers are just that fast. Willie Jones, on drums, was amazing. He played a cyborg robot on fire... always perfect, yet with intense passion as needed. (And somehow without breaking a sweat, even in a suit under the stage lights). Rick Germanson (whose family was seated two tables over from us) was amazing on piano. The new kid, Luke Sellick on bass, kept up well all night but was a little rough in the solos. Overall, it's a great experience. Like seeing music at a friend's house. If, someone, your friend new some of the greatest jazz musicians in the world.The focus here is on the music, but the food here is pretty good as well. The first two sets of every evening are for dinner guests; they recommend you arrive an hour early to have time to eat. Prices are perhaps a bit of the high side, especially given the somewhat hefty coverage charge for the music (the cover charge varies by night, depending on the talent), but the food is good and tasty. The fried chicken is definitely recommended. Given the tight spaces, service is pretty good. The wait staff has gotten pretty good and squeezing into tight spaces, and they are especially good at being unobtrusive, yet still responsive, once the music starts. On a night with major talent in the house it can get pretty expensive (the music charge is $9-40, and then there's dinner, tax, and tip on top of that). There's a serious lake of elbow room. But live jazz, in a small club, is a true New York experience.

Amazing place! Took my boyfriend here for his birthday . Music is amazing, good atmosphere. We had fix price diner for 38$ it's amazing! Every course is delicious, I had salmon and he got lemon chicken . Good wine and cocktails , waiters are very nice ) 5 *

Without a doubt the best jazz experience I've lived. Drinks, barstaff, food, and of course music and atmosphere were all I expected and hoped for. Appreciate the musicians and bartenders, and you'll have a great night!

Very cozy place. If I could give half stars, this place gets a 4.5.Unlike other jazz clubs, the food here is actually pretty good. We got the 3-course Fixed Price menu for $38. Brussel Sprouts and Quinoa Fritters were fresh, colorful, and flavorful. It felt like some heart and effort were actually put into these two. The fried chicken was also very good and fatty - you could definitely taste the honey in it. Among the better fried chickens I've had in the city (probably in the top 25th percentile). The presentation of it was enough to make me smile, too. Dessert was a bit subpar though - nothing special about the brownie.Also, they really made the menu vegetarian/vegan friendly which I don't see much in other places of similar cuisine.Service was very tentative.Acoustics were controlled well - great vibe in combination with the space and ambiance. We came through on a night with tenor saxophonist Eric Alexander. An awesome pleasure to listen to.In total, a three course dinner - where the servings were plentiful - along with the ambiance and great music makes this a place well worth visiting. Everything in total was $50 a person (we didn't get drinks).It's a very good deal - jazz fan or not.

I imagine jazz clubs were like this place back in the day: cover charge was minimal but you stayed to drink and hear music and eat if you could afford it. And you could even talk to the musicians after or in between sets, as I did with the gracious trumpeter Duane Eubanks whom I heard here a few weeks ago. The food is quite good but I just had a dessert and a scotch. Perfect.

Intimate, sexy, sophisticated, unbelievable sound acoustics, and great food combine to give you and experience you'll remember for a long time.  My wife and I have been to many jazz venues but never to Smoke. We went there 9/26/15 to see the Buster William Quartet having tried to make last minute dinner reservations for our anniversary but they were full.  We ended up going to the 10:30 pm show and having dessert there instead. We loved it!!  We both have been to a number of music venues but Smoke provides an experience which is a cut above in my opinion. The small room leads to very tightly spaced tables but frankly the ambiance and feel of the place doesn't make you feel like it. The stage sits at the back of the room but the worst seat in the house can't be more than 100 feet away.  They have a limited dessert menu but what they have works, my wife had the Bananas Foster Bread Pudding and I had the Cheesecake which were great. The service was efficient and very polite. Folks all around us were having late dinners and although we were full from just having dinner elsewhere, it all looked so good we seriously debated having dinner a second time.  :-)The small intimate setting, great acoustics and close proximity to the musicians comes at a price.  Smoke is not inexpensive with $38 music charge last night and a $20 food or drink minimum. That said I found their menu prices to be in line with the quality and NYC area.After the 10:30 show they have less well known Jazz artists come in but the O'Neil Group we saw was also excellent and fun.  There's no music charge after midnight but a $20 food/drink minimum that the waitresses waived for us since the room had a few open tables and we had covered the earlier charge.   I would recommend Smoke any time but If you see an early Broadway show in mid-town you can have dinner here late and stay late.  You can also listen to some great music into the early morning hours cheap after midnight any time. Highly recommended!
